wiki.content:
The single has so far peaked at #1 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart, as well as topping the Billboard R&B Songs chart. It has also become Thicke's most successful song on the Billboard Hot 100, being his first to reach #1 (he previously climbed as high as #14 with Lost Without U, back in 2007). The song has been a worldwide hit and reached number #1 in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Ireland, the Netherlands, the UK, and the United States as well as the top 10 in Belgium, Denmark, France, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and Switzerland. Comparisons have been made between the instrumentation and musical style of "Blurred Lines" and Madonna's 2008 single, "Give It 2 Me", which was also co-written and co-produced by Pharrell Williams.
        
User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License and may also be available under the GNU FDL.

The song has been a worldwide hit and reached number #1 in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Ireland, the Netherlands, the UK, and the United States as well as the top 10 in Belgium, Denmark, France, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and Switzerland.

track.name: Blurred Lines
comments: Probably the worst song ever made.

"This song does not degrade women, my god." "evyn, 24, Male, United States" "I hate these blurred lines I know you want it" "I know you want it But you're a good girl The way you grab me Must wanna get nasty" "When you got them jeans on What do we need steam for You the hottest bitch in this place" "What rhymes with hug me?" "One thing I ask of you Let me be the one you back that ass to" "Yeah, I had a bitch, but she ain't bad as you So hit me up when you passing through I'll give you something big enough to tear your ass in two" "Nothing like your last guy, he too square for you He don't smack that ass and pull your hair like that" "Not many women can refuse this pimpin" you're so right. i think this should be a feminist empowerment anthem, with the way it builds up women and their right to be free from unwanted sexual advances, the right to say no, and the right to not be harassed. thank you robin thicke.
